lg.l: Fair Ones, You who Hearts Command
And Gently sway with Fan in Hand
Your fav'rite Punch a Suppliant falls
And humbly for Assistance calls.He humbly calls and beggs you'll stop
The Gothick Rage of Vander-Hop:
Which Invades without pretence and Right
Or any Law but that of Might
Our Pigmy Lands, and Treats our Kings
Like paultry Ide wooden things
Has beat our Dancers out of Doors
And calls our chastest Virgins Whores,
He has not Left our Queen a Rag on,
Has forc'd away our George and Dragon,
Has broke our Wyres, nor was he civil,
To Doctor Faustus, nor the Devil
Ev'n me he Hurryed with full Rage
Most hoarsly squalling of the Stage;
And faith our fright was very Great
To see a Minister of State
Arm'd with Power and fury come
To force us from our Little Home;
We fear'd as I am sue we'd reason
An Accusation of High Treason:
'Till starting up says 1The name of a Puppet. Banamire
Treason, my friends, we need not fear,
For 'gainst the 2Farthings patent. Brass we us'd no Power,
Nor strove to save the Chancellor,
Nor did we shew the least Affection
To Rochford, or the Meath Election,
Nor did we Sing Mis: Cue, he means
You Villain I'll dash out your Brains
'Tis no Affair of State which Brings
Me here, or Bus'ness of the Kings
I'm come to seize you all as Debtors
And bind you fast in Iron Fetters
From sight of Every Friend in Town
'Till fifty pounds to me paid Down,
Fifty Qouth I, a Devilish sum,
But stay 'till Brass Farthings come,
Then we shall be as rich as Jews
From Castle down to lowest Stews.
That Sum shall then to you be told
Th√¥ now we cannot furnish Gold.
Quoth he, thou Vile Misshapen Beast,
Thou Knave am I become thy jest;
And dost thou think that I am come
To carry nought but Farthings Home
Thou Fool I ne're do things by Halves
Farthings are made for Irish Slaves.
No Brass for me it must be Gold
Or Fifty pounds in Silver Told
That can by any means obtain
Freedom for thee and for thy TrainVotre tres humble Serviteur
I'm not in jest said I. I'm sure,
But from the bottom of my Belly
I in sober sadness tell ye.
I thought it was good reasoning
For us fictitious Men to bring
Brass Counters made by William Wood
Which might as well be Understood
Intrinsick, as we Flesh and Blood.
Then since we are but Mimmick men
Pray let us pay in Mimmick Coyn
Quoth he, thou lovest Punch to prate,
And could for ever hold Debate,
But thinkest thou I've nought to do
But to stand prating thus to you
Therefore to stop your noisy parly
I at once assure you fairly,
That not a Puppet of you all
Shall stir a Step without this Wall
Nor merry Andrew Beat the Drum
Untill you pay the Aforesaid sum.Y08B760L
